div.head: Somewhere over the rainbow, way up high
div.p: There's a land that I've heard of once in a lullaby.

Everyone knows "Over the Rainbow," the song made famous by a young Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz. The song was intended to take viewers to an imagined fantasy landa place of yearning and hope, distant, abstract, and hypothetical. Importantly, the song was performed at quite a slow tempo (around 72 beats per minute (NoteDiscover, n.d.). Now imagine listening to Judy Garland singing her song at a much faster tempo. Would you still be carried on the wings of the song to a distant and abstract place? Probably not. Judy Garland's original "Over the Rainbow" invites the listener to transcend the here and now; to travel along a pivotal organizing dimension of conscious experiencethat of psychological distance. This is a process we engage in every time we think of a future plan, hear news about a distant location, take the perspective of a friend, or simulate what might have been. Critically, ample evidence suggests that this mental travel is enabled by shifts in the level at which we construe the involved objects and events (Liberman et al., 2007;Trope & Liberman, 2010).

The attempt to map elements of conscious experience, their connections and interactions, has occupied experimental psychologists for generations. Structural psychology (Titchener, 1909), the study of semantic space and meaning dimensions (e.g., Osgood & Suci, 1955), and the conceptual metaphor approach (Landau et al., 2010) all reflect an endeavor to better understand the structure of the mind and of human experience. In the spirit of this endeavor we examine the as-yet unstudied possibility that both psychological distance and its representational counterpartconstrual levelare associated with another central dimension of consciousness: that of stimulus speed. We further propose that these associations exert subtle effects on subjective experience and may hold implications for domains as varied as communication, person perception, decision making, behavioral intentions, negotiation, urban design and more.

div.head: Psychological Distance and Construal Level
div.p: A critical attribute of objects and events in our world is that they vary with respect to how close or distant they are from the "point of direct experience" -i.e., one's own self in the here and now (Liberman et al., 2007;Trope & Liberman, 2010, p. 440). Psychological distance is the subjective experience of the extent to which objects are removed from this zero-distance point. Objects can be removed in space (near versus far); time (close versus removed in the future or the past); the social dimension (applying to someone more versus less known to us, or more versus less similar to us); and hypotheticality (real or likely versus imaginary or unlikely).

An object's psychological distance affects its subjective meaning and its potential implications for the self here and now. Indeed, whether something is real or hypothetical, as well as how distant it is from us in space, time, and social perspective, is of utmost importance for functioning and survival. It can determine whether the object poses a risk to us, whether and to what extent we can benefit from it, whether and how we should prepare to act on it, whether and how we can appropriate it, how much information we have about it, and much more.
This centrality of psychological distance is reflected in studies of the semantic space.

In their efforts to measure meaning, Osgood and Suci (1955) identified three culturally universal factors that define the semantic space, each capturing to a greater or lesser degree physical attributes and subjective perceptionsevaluation (i.e., good-bad), potency (e.g., strong-weak), and activity (e.g., active-passive). Bentler and LaVoie (1972) expanded this list to include seven dimensions, adding density (e.g., many-few), orderliness (e.g., constantchangeable), familiarity (e.g., common-rare), and reality (or, as we might say, hypotheticality e.g., imaginary-real, abstract-concrete). Similarly reflecting its centrality, psychological distance is accessed automatically, even when extracting such information is not one of a person's explicit current goals (Bar-Anan et al., 2007).

Construal level theory (CLT; Liberman & Trope, 1998;2008;2014;Trope & Liberman, 2010) suggests, and extensive empirical evidence establishes, that the four dimensions of psychological distance are interrelated, such that psychological distance forms one integral dimension of subjective experience. Indeed, thinking about distant places (spatial distance) invokes the distant rather than the near future (temporal distance), other people rather than oneself (social distance), and unlikely rather than likely events (hypotheticality) (Fiedler et al., 2012;2014;Trope & Liberman, 2010). For example, Bar-Anan et al. (2007) showed that participants respond faster to words connoting psychological proximity (e.g., "tomorrow," "friend") when these are presented at a proximal point in an image of a landscape compared with a distal point, whereas the reverse is true for words connoting psychological distance (e.g., "year," "enemy").

CLT further proposes that people engage with the world that lies beyond the here and now by using abstraction to represent objects that are more psychologically distant. It is assumed that high-level construals (e.g., abstract categories, high-level goals) suit better the representation of psychologically distant stimuli because they are more likely than low-level construals (e.g., concrete exemplars, low-level goals) to remain unchanged as one gets closer to an object or farther away. Thus, while psychological distance is the subjective experience of the extent to which objects are removed from the point of direct experience, construal level refers to how objects are represented in our mind.

Ample evidence supports the association between psychological distance and construal level Gamoran et al., 2023;Liberman et al., 2002;Sodeberg et al., 2015;Wakslak & Trope, 2009). For example, in an implicit association task, participants were faster to respond in trials where high-level stimuli (e.g., animals) were paired with psychologically distant stimuli (e.g., a year) and low-level stimuli (e.g., poodle) were paired with psychologically close stimuli (e.g., soon) compared with the reverse. This finding held for all four dimensions of psychological distance (Bar-Anan et al., 2006). The present research adds to the well-established link between construal level and psychological distance by showing that both also have predictable associations with a seemingly unrelated dimension speed.

div.head: Speed
div.p: Just as all stimuli can be described in terms of their spatial distance from a target, all stimuli can be described in terms of their speed (even if this speed is zero). In turn, the mind has evolved to perceive and assess this characteristic. This makes sense, given that an object's speedthe speed of an approaching car, a slamming door, a prey animal bolting awaycan have huge implications. Together with an object's spatial distance, its speed is critical in determining the specific defensive behavior that it activates (Fanselow, 1994;Maren, 2007;Mobbs et al., 2007). The high loading of the fast-slow scale on the "activity" factor described above (.70;Osgood & Suci, 1955) reflects the centrality of speed as a dimension of meaning.

Despite its great importance as a meaning dimension, speed has attracted scarce research attention. In a notable exception, Ben-Haim et al. (2015) found that much like valence (Bargh et al., 1996) and psychological distance (Bar-Anan et al. 2007), the speed of an object is automatically extracted even when this information is completely irrelevant to the task at hand. Specifically, participants were faster both to name pictures of objects characterized by high velocity (e.g., a rocket) and to read words naming such objects compared with objects characterized by slow velocity (e.g., a wheelchair). The same pattern emerged when an object's apparent velocity was manipulated through context. For example, a car depicted driving downhill was named more quickly than a car shown driving uphill (see Matlock, 2004, for related findings).

div.head: Speed, Spatial Distance, Psychological Distance, and Construal Level
div.p: Thus far, we have seen that the different dimensions of psychological distance (spatial, temporal, social, and hypothetical) map onto each other, as do psychological distance and construal level. We have also seen that both psychological distance and speed are accessed automatically even when extracting this information is not one of a person's conscious goals.
Here we probe into whether and how the speed dimension of meaning is associated in the mind with psychological distance and construal level.

In CLT, one way to explain the relation between psychological distance and abstraction is based on logical-functional principles (Gilead et al., 2020(Gilead et al., , 2021. Similar logical-functional principles suggest a relation between speed and both psychological distance and abstraction. First, other things being equal, spatially distant objects take longer to affect us, and in that sense are slower to affect us. All else being equal, a pizza delivered from the other side of town (vs. from a nearby restaurant) will take longer to satiate our hunger, and in that sense has a slower effect. Similarly, a snake two meters away could bite us sooner (and thus "faster") than a snake two blocks away. Thus, the spatial distance of a stimulus and the speed with which it affects the self here and now are logically associated. Second, other things being equal, slower objects will necessarily affect us later in time. For example, a slowly moving car heading our way will hit us later than a fast-moving car. Thus, speed and temporal distance are logically associated. Because the other two dimensions of psychological distancesocial distance and hypothetical distanceare associated (in reality and in our minds) with spatial distance and temporal distance and are automatically activated by them, a stimulus's speed may very well be associated with psychological distance more generally. We thus hypothesize an association between the speed of a stimulus and its psychological distance, such that what is psychologically distant is "slow," and what is psychologically close is "fast" (Hypothesis 1).

Speed and level of construal are also logically related, for the same reason that, according to CLT, the latter is associated with psychological distance. Specifically, low-level features, being specific, secondary, and context-dependent, change faster across time, space, social worlds, and hypothetical worlds. High-level features, in contrast, being general, primary, and context-independent, change more slowly (see Gilead et al., 2020;Hansen & Trope, 2013). Indeed, in CLT high-level construals are assumed to "smooth out" low-level, local, and idiosyncratic variation, rendering the representation of an object more stable across distance . For example, personality characteristics or the function of a tool change more slowly than specific behaviors or a tool's appearance (Trope & Liberman, 2010).

Note that speed of change is related to but not identical with speed of motion. In the language of calculus, speed of change is the first derivative of any quantity as a function of time, such that a speed of zero implies no change. The change involved may relate to the position of an object relative to other objects, as in the case of motion (e.g., the speed of an approaching car, or of floating dots on a screen), but it may also be a change in some other quality of an object, as when things grow, or when a situation develops. In that sense, "speed of change" is the more general construct, of which "speed of motion" is a specific case, in which the change in question is a change in location relative to other objects or to a reference point.

We thus further hypothesize an association between the speed of a stimulus and its construal level, such that what is abstract (a high construal level) is "slow" and what is concrete (a low construal level) is "fast" (Hypothesis 2).

The hypothesized associations are also consistent with a cognitive-ecological approach to cognition (Fiedler, 2014(Fiedler, , 2020Pleskac & Hertwig, 2014;and see also Brunswik, 1955;Gigerenzer et al., 2012;Lewin, 1951). This approach suggests that "in order to understand intrapsychic processes within the human mind, it is necessary to analyze the structure and constraints of the stimulus environment impinging on the mind" (Fiedler, 2014, p. 659). In other words, the structure of the feedback from our interaction with the environment shapes what we learn.

One inevitable regularity of our interaction with the environment is that as objects move relative to us, images of stimuli that are farther away from us move more slowly on the retina. This very basic association between a stimulus's speed and its distance serves as a pivotal cue of depth perception, called motion parallax (Gibson, 1950): what moves faster on the retina is closer, what moves slower on the retina is further away. As succinctly put by Helmholtz: "The apparent angular velocities of objects in the field of view will be inversely proportional to their real distances away; and consequently safe conclusions can be drawn as to the real distance of the body" (Helmholtz, 1925, p. 295). Thus, spatial distance and speed are interrelated in our experience.

The mental association between the spatial distance of a stimulus and the speed with which it may affect the self obviously serves an important survival function. This explains the well-established relationship between a stimulus's spatial distance, its position in the visual field, and the speed of our response to it. Spatially close stimuli are prevalent in the lower visual field, below eye level, whereas spatially distant stimuli are prevalent in the upper visual field, above eye level. Importantly, people generally respond more quickly to stimuli in the lower part of the visual field compared with the upper part (Previc, 1990). A related finding is that spatial distance from a threatening stimulus affects our choice of behavioral strategy, and specifically whether we deploy a slower, more complex avoidance strategy or a fast, reflexive one (fight/flight). Perceiving a more distant threatening stimulus activates the prefrontal cortex, which regulates slower, more complex planning. As the threatening stimulus gets closer, regions in the midbrain (the central amygdala and periaqueductal gray) which regulate fast, reflexive behaviors (fight or flight) gain control (Maren, 2007;Mobbs et al., 2007).

From the perspective of the cognitive ecological approach, these built-in associations in our interaction with the environment between spatial distance and speed give rise to an association between these two dimensions of meaning. As noted before, distance on other dimensions (temporal, social, and hypothetical) as well as level of construal are associated in our experience with more spatial distance and are automatically activated by it. Given that spatial distance is repeatedly coupled in our experience with speed, it should then follow that from the perspective of cognitive ecological approach, too, 1what is psychologically distant is "slow," and what is psychologically close is "fast" (Hypothesis 1); and 2what is abstract (a high construal level) is "slow," and what is concrete (a low construal level) is "fast" (Hypothesis 2).

Finally, it may be tempting to view the hypothesized associations between speed, psychological distance, and construal level as of purely theoretical interest. We argue here that in fact, the hypothesized associations have many practical ramifications and empirically examine their implications in two domains: communication and person perception.

Specifically, we propose that changes in the speed of speech may affect aspects of the perceived relationship between speaker and audience and the perceived regulatory scope of the speaker, with faster-paced speech perceived as contracting both aspects of the relationship with the audience (Hypothesis 3) and the speaker's perceived regulatory scope (Hypothesis 4).

div.head: The Current Research
div.p: The current research consists of twelve studies in three study sets. Study Set I examines the hypothesized association between speed and psychological distance. If indeed this association exists, it may result in (at least) four kinds of effects: an implicit association between the two dimensions (Hypothesis 1a), an experienced compatibility between the two (Hypothesis 1b), an effect of stimulus psychological distance on its perceived speed (Hypothesis 1c), and conversely, an effect of stimulus speed on its perceived psychological distance (Hypothesis 1d). These hypotheses were examined in four studies. Study 1 tested whether people implicitly associate psychological distance and speed, and whether people experience compatibility between the dimensions as reflected in an explicit association between them (H1a, H1b). Study 2 examined whether participants' preferences reflect an experienced compatibility between dissimilar (psychologically distant) words and slow music and between similar (psychologically close) words and fast music (H1b). Study 3 examined the effect of psychological distance on perceived speed, testing whether people conceive the pace of life in psychologically distant places as slow and in psychologically near places as fast (H1c). Study 4 considered the converse effect, testing whether people experience acts performed slowly as more imaginary and less real than acts performed quickly (H1d).

div.head: Study Set II examines the hypothesized association between speed and construal level.
div.p: This association may result in (at least) five kinds of effects: an implicit association between the two dimensions (Hypothesis 2a), an experienced compatibility between the two (Hypothesis 2b), a compatibility in their appearance in natural language (Hypothesis 2c), an effect of stimulus construal level on its speed (Hypothesis 2d), and an effect of stimulus speed on its preferred construal level (Hypothesis 2e). To examine these hypotheses, we ran five studies. Study 5 was similar to Study 1, but with construal level instead of psychological distance (H2a, H2b). Study 6 empirically examined whether participants' preferences reflect an experienced compatibility between abstract words and slow music and between concrete words and fast music (H2b). In Study we examined whether the hypothesized association between abstractness and speed is supported by the structure of word distribution in natural language (H2c). Study 8 examined the effect of construal level on speed, testing whether situations characterized by more abstract verbs are perceived as slower to change (H2d).

Study 9 examined the effect of speed on construal level, testing whether actions imagined as performed slowly are construed at a higher level (in terms of goals rather than means) compared with actions imagined as performed quickly (H2e).

Finally, Study Set III examines implications of the hypothesized associations between speed, psychological distance, and construal level for the domains of communication (Hypothesis 3) and person perception (Hypothesis 4). In Study 10a we examined whether the speed of recorded messages is associated with the perceived spatial distance between the speaker and her audience (H3a), with the perceived social distance between the speaker and her audience (H3b), and with perceived audience size (H3c). Study 10b extends the results of Study 10a to spoken messages in a foreign language. In Study 11 we examined whether people infer an expansive regulatory scope from slow-paced spoken speech, and a contractive regulatory scope from fast-paced speech (H4).

div.head: General Methodology
div.p: All the studies but four (Studies 1, 5, 7, and 8) were conducted in Hebrew. Participants were Hebrew-speaking Israeli university students and graduates aged 18-40 with no learning disabilities. They were recruited via one of two Israeli platforms (Panel4All and Hamidgam), and were instructed to complete the study in a quiet place from beginning to end with no breaks. The studies were presented to participants as focusing on intuitive information processing. Participants were encouraged to follow their gut feelings. Participants were allocated randomly to experimental conditions and to versions of the studies. IRB approval and protocol number -3470.

div.head: Transparency and Openness
div.p: Preregistration. Eleven of the 12 reported studies (all but Study 7) were preregistered (designs, hypotheses and analysis plans). Links to all preregistrations are available in the Electronic Supplementary Materials (ESM). 1 Sample Size. Sample sizes for all studies were determined a-priori based on power analyses conducted using G*Power (Faul et al., 2013). In Studies 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 10a, 10b and 11, we assumed either a small-to-medium or a medium effect (d = 0.3-0.5, η 2 p = .06) in a two-tailed test. The analyses suggested we should recruit 88-128 participants to achieve 80%

power. As we ran the studies in noisy conditions (online), we aimed to recruit additional 20-30 participants for each study. We therefore collected data from 108-150 respondents in each study. Computations of sample sizes for Studies 1 and 5 are described in their respective Participants sections.

Exclusions. In all studies except two (Studies 1 and 5) we excluded participants based on any of four criteria: taking excessive amounts of time to complete the study (over an hour and more than 3 SDs longer than the mean completion time); showing zero variance on the DV; failure to follow instructions; and reporting technical issues. In Studies 2 and 6 we also considered excluding participants on the basis of extreme difficulty or lack of enjoyment with the experimental task, because of the risk that these participants might have had trouble relying on their gut feelings. However, none of our participants reported extreme levels on these variables, and we made no exclusions based on these criteria. In Studies 10b and 11, which used stimuli in Finnish to create the experience of hearing a foreign language, we also excluded participants who reported knowing Finnish or understanding any of the message.
These exclusion criteria were preregistered.

Data availability. All data and codes associated with this manuscript are openly available in a public repository. All research materials are available at the OSF and can be accessed at https://osf.io/wmhvb/.

div.head: Study Set I
div.p: Study Set I examines the hypothesized association between speed and psychological distance (Hypothesis 1).

div.head: Study 1: Implicit and Explicit Associations Between Psychological Distance and Speed
div.p: This study examines whether people implicitly associate words or phrases conveying psychological distance (e.g., "in 10 years," "in a distant land") with words conveying the concept slow (e.g., "slowness," "slower"), and words conveying psychological proximity (e.g., "this evening," "next door") with words conveying the concept fast (e.g., "speedy,"

"rapid"). To measure an implicit association between the two dimensions, participants completed a sorting paired features task (SPF; Bar-Anan et al., 2009). The study further examined whether people experience compatibility between the dimensions by measuring explicit associations between the two sets of concepts using visual analog scales (VAS).

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. Participants were recruited from Project Implicit's participant pool (http://implicit.harvard.edu; Nosek, 2005). Because this was the first study to test for the hypothesized effects, we sought to maximize the odds of detecting a small-to-medium effect Implicit Association Measure. In the SPF, participants categorized pairs of words or phrases (e.g., "Far, far away" + "Slowly") into one of four pairs of categories (Far+Slow, Far+Fast, Near+Slow, Near+Fast) in three blocks of 40 trials (see Fig. 1). Each pair included one of four words or phrases representing psychological distance ("in 10 years," "far, far away," "once upon a time," "in a distant land") or psychological proximity ("right here,"

"right now," "next door," "next evening") and one of four words representing slowness ("slow," "slower," "slowness," "slowly") or speed ("fast," "rapid," "quick," "speedy"). Faster response times for categorizing pairs of words or phrases from one category pair (e.g., Far+Slow) compared to another (e.g., Far+Fast) can be interpreted as indicating stronger associations for the former than for the latter.

Following standard procedure for computing scores for the SPF (Bar-Anan et al., 2009), we examined whether participants showed stronger implicit associations between word pairs that matched the combinations Far+Slow and Near+Fast over pairs that matched

Far+Fast and Near+Slow. Specifically, we first computed the difference between average response latency in trials where the target pairs matched either of the combinations Far+Slow or Near+Fast, and that in trials where the match was to Far+Fast or Near+Slow. This difference was computed for each of the three SPF blocks, then divided by the overall standard deviation of that block to produce that block's SPF D score. The average of the three SPF D scores (one for each block) was the overall SPF D score, used as the measure of implicit associations. Positive SPF D scores indicated stronger associations for the combinations which were congruent with the hypothesis (Far+Slow and Near+Fast) than for the incongruent combinations (Far+Fast and Near+Slow).

In the SPF, each of the four category combinations is located in the corner of a square, such that the categories belonging to one dimension are separated vertically and those belonging to the other dimension are separated horizontally (see Fig. 1). In this study, combinations containing the category Far were always positioned in the two top corners of the square, and combinations containing Near in the bottom corners, so as to avoid conflict with the natural appearance of physically close stimuli in the lower visual field and of distant stimuli in the upper visual field (Bruno & Cutting, 1988;Cutting & Vishton, 1995;Previc, 1990Previc, , 1998Previc et al., 2005;Yonas et al., 2002). We manipulated between participants whether the categories Slow and Fast appeared in the left-or right-hand corners. The E and C keys were used to indicate the upper and lower left corners, respectively, and the I and N keys the upper and lower right corners. Participants were asked to put their left middle and index fingers on the E and C keys, and their right middle and index fingers on the I and N keys. Explicit Association Measure. Following the SPF, participants completed one of two self-report questionnaires. Half the participants were given each of the eight words or phrases used for psychological distance and psychological proximity in the SPF task, and were asked to indicate for each one whether they associated it more with the concept Slow or the concept indicating stronger associations between psychological distance and Slow and between psychological proximity and Fast than the reverse. We also examined whether the effect on the SPF scores depends on the positioning of the two speed concepts (i.e., whether Slow was to the left or the right; this analysis was not preregistered). Associations with Distance. For those questionnaires where participants were asked to associate the speed words with psychological distance versus proximity, we submitted the average reported associations (detailed in Table 1) to a 2 (speed: Slow, Fast) x 2 (concept on the left of the VAS: Far, Near) mixed ANOVA. The results can be found in the lower panel of was on the left size of the VAS than when it was on the right, F(1, 127) = 9.14, p = . 003, η 2 p = .07, 95% CI [0.01, 0.16]. There was no significant interaction, F(1, 127) = 1.42, p = . 234, η 2 p = .01, 95% CI [0.00, 0.07]. Thus, the results indicate that participants explicitly associate slowness more than speed with the category Far (rather than Near).

In sum, the results of Study 1 support Hypothesis 1a, suggesting that people automatically associate psychological distance (far vs. near) with speed (slow vs. fast). They further support Hypothesis 1b, suggesting that people experience a compatibility between the dimensions: participants explicitly associated words and phrases reflecting psychological distance (rather than proximity) with the concept "slow" (rather than "fast"), and they consciously associated words reflecting slowness with psychological distance.

Note that in this study, psychological distance was represented only by its spatial and temporal dimensions. The following studies examine our hypothesis with respect to all four dimensions of psychological distance.

div.head: Study 2: Compatibility between Psychological Distance and Speed
div.p: Study 2 was designed to examine Hypothesis 1b using a different methodology, while also extending our investigation to all four dimensions of psychological distance.

We asked participants to follow their gut feeling in matching each of two words, one reflecting psychological distance and the other reflecting psychological proximity, to two boxes, one labeled "slow music" and the other "fast music." We expected participants to match words connoting psychological distance to the "slow music" box, and words connoting psychological proximity words to the "fast music" box, with probability greater than chance (i.e., greater than 50%).

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. One hundred twenty-four participants (80 females, Mage = 27.52, SD = 4.33) participated in the study (see the description of the sample pool under "The Current Research" above). Three were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM under Exclusion of Participants). This left a final sample of 121 participants.

Materials and Procedure. Participants were asked to imagine two pieces of music, first a slow passage and then a fast one. They were then told that their task would be to choose which of the two categories of music (slow or fast) is a better fit for songs on different themes. In each trial, participants were presented with two boxes, one labeled "slow music" and the other labeled "fast music," along with a pair of wordsallegedly the themes of two songs. They were asked to match each of the two words to the type of music that suits it better by dragging and dropping them into the appropriate box (see Fig. 2). Participants were assured that there were no right or wrong answers in this task and were encouraged to follow their gut feelings. Participants were presented with pairs of words, comprising three pairs for each of the four dimensions of psychological distance (spatial, temporal, social, and hypotheticality).
In each pair, one word connoted psychological distance (e.g., "there," "later," "theirs,"

"imaginary") and the other psychological proximity (e.g., "here," "now," "ours," "real"). The two words in each pair had the same number of syllables. The two words were presented sideby-side to the right of the two boxes, midway up, with their order randomly determined. The position of the "slow music" box to the left or to the right of the "fast music" box was counterbalanced across participants in two versions of the experiment.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: The proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.78 (SD = 0.22). A t-test comparing this proportion with the constant 0.5 yielded a significant difference, t(120) = 13.78, p < .0001, d = 1.25, 95% CI [1.01, 1.49]. We also examined the effect separately for each of the experimental versions and for each of the four dimensions of psychological distance (this analysis was not preregistered). The effect did not vary across experimental versions (M =0.78, SD = 0.21, with the "fast music" box on the right; M =0.78, SD =0.23, with the "slow music" box on the right, t < 1). Furthermore, the effect emerged for each of the four dimensions of psychological distance: spatial, t(120) = 7.83, p < . versus proximity are experienced as compatible with slowness versus speed, respectively.

div.head: Study 3: The Effect of Psychological Distance on Perceived Speed
div.p: If indeed psychological distance and speed are associated, then the psychological distance of a stimulus may affect its perceived speed (Hypothesis 1c; for a similar rationale see Cian et al., 2015;Nussinson et al., 2019;. In this study we asked participants to think about someplace physically distant from or close to their own location, and then to rate that place's pace of life. We hypothesized that participants would perceive the pace of life of physically distant (close) places as slow (fast).

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. One hundred and fifty volunteers (96 females, Mage = 28.30, SD = 3.89 participated in the study. Three were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM 4 ). Thus, 147 participants were included in the analysis.

Materials and Procedure. Participants read that there are places where the pace of life is slow and everything seems to move slowly, and others where the pace of life is fast and everything seems to move quickly. They were then asked to take a moment to think about a place which is very distant from (close to) where they are now. Next, they were asked to imagine the pace of life in that distant (close) place and to indicate it on a 175 mm slider anchored at "very slow" on the left and "very fast" on the right. Distance from the left end of the slider (1-100) served as the dependent variable (higher numbers indicate a faster pace of life). As a manipulation check we asked participants how close by or far away they imagined the place to be on a scale from 1 (very close) to 7 (very far).

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: As hypothesized ( A possible concern is that asking participants to call to mind a "distant" place prompted them to think of a rural locale, and that this artifact rather than psychological distance per se underlies the result. Future research may ask participants who live close to or far from the selfsame place to consider its pace of life (while controlling for the pace of life in participants' own place of residence).

div.head: Study 4: The Effect of Speed on Psychological Distance
div.p: If indeed psychological distance and speed are associated, then the speed of a stimulus may affect its psychological distance (Hypothesis 1d; for a similar rationale see Cian et al., 2015;Nussinson et al., 2019;. The hypotheticality dimension of psychological distance has two aspectsthe likelihood that a certain event will happen, and the degree to which a certain object or event is real vs. unreal or imaginary (Bar-Anan et al., 2006). This study focuses on the latter. We asked participants to visualize a certain behavior being performed slowly or fast, and then to rate how imaginary or real they perceived it to be. We hypothesized that participants would perceive behaviors performed slowly as more imaginary (less real) than behaviors performed quickly.

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. One hundred and twenty participants (87 females, Mage = 29.23, SD = 4.56) took part in the study. Seven were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM). Thus, the analyzed sample had participants.

Materials and Procedure. Participants read that there are moments and situations in life where everything happens fast, and other moments and situations where everything happens slowly. For each of 20 common behaviors expressed in a few words (borrowed from Vallacher & Wegner, 1989; e.g., opening a door) participants were asked to picture it happening either slowly or quickly. Their task was to indicate how imaginary versus real they experienced the behavior to be. They were asked to indicate their judgment on a 175 mm slider from "real" on the left to "imaginary" on the right. Distance from the left end of the slider (1-100) served as the dependent variable (lower numbers indicate greater perceived reality).

To strengthen the speed manipulation, participants were presented at the start of each trial with an animation in which colorful dots were seen floating inside a rectangle (480px X 320px) either slowly or quickly. They were told that the moving dots simulated the speed at which they should imagine the following action being performed. The speed at which each action was to be imagined was counterbalanced across the two versions of the experiment. To ensure the robustness of the manipulation, after reading the instructions participants were shown the two versions of the animation and were asked to indicate in which one the dots were moving slowly. Finally, as a manipulation check, at the end of the study participants were asked to rate the speed of the fast-moving and slow-moving dots on a scale from 1 (very slow) to 7 (very fast). Analysis of participants' ratings (not preregistered) yielded a strong and significant effect (see ESM-Study4-AnalysisOfManipulationCheck).

Note that in both conditions participants were asked to imagine a behavior being performed, and then rate the degree to which they thought of the behavior as occurring in reality versus in the realm of the imagination. To ensure that participants' ratings on the perceived reality-imagination scale did indeed reflect variation on the hypotheticality dimension, we conducted an auxiliary study, in which we asked 42 participants to imagine having dinner with a person of their choice, then to write a few sentences describing the dinner, and finally to rate the scene they had imagined on the reality-imagination scale (the same scale that we use in the current study). Participants were then asked to describe the extent to which the imagined scene was dim or sharp, vague or vivid, sketchy or detailed, and whether it was in black and white or in color, all on scales from 1 to 7. These four items were borrowed from the Memory Characteristics Questionnaire (Johnson et al., 1988). Participants

were further asked to answer seven questions aimed at assessing their psychological distance from the event and its level of construal: the degree to which (1) they served in the imagined event as observer or participant;

(2) the general character of the event was vague or vivid; the scene's imagined location was (3) blurry or clear, (4) distant or close, and (5) unknown or familiar; (6) the imagined event could take place only in the distant future or in the very near future; and (7) the person imagined in the scene was socially distant (someone they barely knew) or socially close (a family member or close friend). Participants indicated their ratings on a scale from 1 to 7. The 11 items were highly correlated (Cronbach's α = .861).

Importantly, an index combining these items positively and substantially correlated with the reality-imagination ratings of the dinner, r(40) = .579, p = .001. It thus seems that the perceived reality-imagination ratings provided by participants can indeed reflect variation on the hypotheticality dimension (see ESM-Study 4-Validation of DV-DATA and Code).

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: Some behaviors (e.g., brushing one's teeth) were rated as more real than others (e.g., climbing a tree). To take out this irrelevant source of variance, participants' ratings for each behavior were normalized across versions (this part of data preparation was not preregistered).
To test Hypothesis 1d, we conducted a (speed: Slow vs. Fast) X 2 (version: 1 vs. 2) mixed

ANOVA with the first variable as a within-participants factor and the second as a betweenparticipants factor. As hypothesized, we found an effect of speed on the perceived reality of the behavior, F(1, 111) = 32.04, p < .0001, η 2 p = .22, 95% CI [0.10, 0.35]. Behaviors visualized as performed quickly were perceived as more real (M = -0.17, SD = 0.45) than those visualized as performed slowly (M = 0.17, SD = 0.53). This effect did not depend on the version of the questionnaire, F(1, 111) = 0.12, p = .727, η 2 p = .00, 95% CI [0.00, 0.04] for the interaction. The results thus support the hypothesis that stimulus speed affects its psychological distance.

Altogether, the results of Study Set I established that people automatically associate speed and psychological distance (Hypothesis 1a), that they experience compatibility between the two dimensions (Hypothesis 1b), that psychological distance affects perceived speed (Hypothesis 1c), and that at least under some conditions speed affects psychological distance (Hypothesis 1d). These results strongly suggest the existence of a bi-directional association between psychological distance and the speed dimension of meaning.

div.head: Study Set II
div.p: Study Set II examines the hypothesized association between speed and construal level (Hypothesis 2).

div.head: Study 5: Implicit and Explicit Associations Between Construal Level and Speed
div.p: In Study 5 we used the same procedure as in Study 1 to examine whether people implicitly associate words conveying abstractness (e.g., "general," "aim") with words conveying the concept slow (e.g., "slowness," "slower"), and words conveying concreteness (e.g., "specific," "means") with words conveying the concept fast (e.g., "speedy," "rapid").
We further examined whether people experience compatibility between these concepts and words.

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. As in Study 1, participants were recruited from Project Implicit's participant pool (http://implicit.harvard.edu; Nosek, 2005). Again, to maximize the odds of obtaining our hypothesized effect, we aimed for 99.9% power, which would enable us to detect a small effect (d = 0.2). A power analysis indicated that 462 participants would be required. Among volunteers randomly assigned to this study, 902 consented to participate, and 499 completed the SPF task.
Following Bar-Anan et al. (2009), of the 499 participants who completed the SPF, we excluded 24 participants (4.80% of the sample) who responded either too quickly (RT < 400)

or too slowly (RT > 10,000) in more than 10% of the trials. Implicit Association Measure. In the SPF, participants categorized pairs of words (e.g., "why" + "slowly") into one of four pairs of categories (Abstract+Slow, Abstract+Fast, Concrete+Slow, Concrete+Fast) in three blocks of 40 trials (see Fig. 3). Each word pair included one of four words representing a high construal level ("abstract," "general," "why," "aim") or a low construal level ("concrete," "specific," "how," "means"), and one of four words representing slowness ("slow," "slower," "slowness," "slowly") or speed ("fast," "rapid," "quick," "speedy"). As in Study 1, faster response times for categorizing word pairs from one category pair compared to another can be interpreted as indicating stronger associations for the former. This time we examined whether participants preferred word pairs that matched the combinations Abstract+Slow and Concrete+Fast over pairs that matched Abstract+Fast and Concrete+Slow. Positive SPF D scores indicated stronger associations for the former than for the latter.

In this study, combinations containing the category Abstract were always positioned in the two top corners of the square, and combinations containing Concrete in the bottom corners (see Fig. 3), so as to avoid conflict with the established association between high construal level and up and between low construal level and down (Nussinson et al., 2019;. We manipulated between participants whether the categories Slow and Fast appeared in the left-or right-hand corners. Explicit Association Measure. Half the participants were given each of the eight words used for the construal-level concepts, and were asked to indicate for each one whether they associated it more with the concept Slow or the concept Fast (e.g., "Do you associate the concept 'specific' more with the concept 'Slow' or the concept 'Fast'?"). They indicated their answers using a visual analog scale ranging from Slow to Fast (we randomly assigned one of the concepts to the left side of the VAS and the other to the right In sum, our results suggest that although people do not implicitly associate construal level (abstract vs. concrete) with speed (slow vs. fast), they do experience a compatibility between the two dimensions, and hence an explicit association between them, in both directions: words denoting high (vs. low) construal level were rated as more slow (rather than fast), and words denoting slowness were rated as more abstract (rather than concrete).

div.head: Study 6: Compatibility between Construal Level and Speed
div.p: In light of the results of Study 5, Study 6 was designed to examine whether people experience abstract concepts as compatible with slowness and concrete concepts as compatible with speed. We asked participants to follow their "gut feeling" in matching each of two words, one reflecting an abstract concept and the other a concrete concept, to two boxes, one labeled "slow music" and the other "fast music." We expected participants to match abstract words to the "slow music" box and concrete words to the "fast music" box with probability greater than chance.

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. One hundred and twenty-two volunteers (83 females, Mage = 28.98, SD = 3.99) participated in the study. Five were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM). Thus, 117 participants were included in the analysis.

Materials and Procedure. We used the same procedure as in Study 2. Participants were presented with 20 pairs of words (allegedly themes of songs). In each pair, one word represented an abstract concept (e.g., "custom," "meaning") and the other a concrete object

Running Head: SPEED PSYCHOLOGICAL DISTANCE AND CONSTRUAL LEVEL (e.g., "pin," "bread"). The words were chosen based on the concreteness ratings published by Brysbaert et al. (2014), such that the concreteness ratings of the concrete words were significantly higher than those of the abstract words, t(19) = 21.49, p < .001. In selecting the words, we ensured that the concrete and abstract words did not differ in valence (based on norms by Warriner et al., 2013), 6 t(19) = .39, p = .699, BF01 = 4.02, or in their frequency in the Hebrew language, t(19) = .51, p = .880, BF01 = 4.26 (based on Frost & Plaut, 2005). In addition, the abstract word and its concrete counterpart were chosen such that they had the same number of syllables. The two words were presented side-by-side to the right of the two boxes, midway up, with their order randomly determined, and the position of the "slow music" box to the left or right was counterbalanced across participants in two versions of the experiment.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: The proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.60 (SD =

div.head: Study 7: Natural Language Processing and the Association Between Abstractness and
Speed
div.p: Research conducted within the framework of computational social science suggests that analyzing word-use within large-scale natural language corporaalso known as natural language processing (NLP)can shed light on how people represent the relationships between different concepts (Bhatia, 2017;Caliskan et al., 2017;Garg et al., 2018).

Underlying this research is the notion that knowledge (i.e., what people know about and associate with different objects and concepts) is reflected in the distribution of words in the language (Firth, 1957;Harris, 1954). Current computational resources allow researchers to measure word distributions on a very large scale and then distill people's mental associations for an enormous number of objects and concepts (Bhatia, 2017(Bhatia, , 2019Bhatia et al., 2018;Dhillon et al., 2011;Jones & Mewhort, 2007;Landauer & Dumais, 1997;Lewis & Lupyan, 2020;Pennington et al., 2014). For example, Caliskan et al. (2017) analyzed the distributional structure of words that are often used as stimuli in implicit association tests (e.g., African
American names vs. European American names) and attitudinal words (e.g., pleasant vs.

unpleasant). Their results showed associations between groups and attitudes which mimic the classic findings of attitude research, i.e., stronger similarity between stereotype-congruent than between stereotype-incongruent pairs of words.

In Study 7 we utilized a popular kind of word distribution-based knowledge representation technique (word embeddings, e.g., Mikolov et al., 2013;Pennington et al., 2014), commonly referred to as vector space semantic models. Such models translate knowledge representations into high-dimensional vectors. These vectors are typically obtained by performing a form of dimensionality reduction on word co-occurrence data. The use of word co-occurrence to obtain representations implies that similar concepts, which are often talked about in language in a similar manner, have similar vector representations and are closer to each other in the semantic spacei.e., they show meaning similarity (e.g., words related to speed, such as quickness, miles-per-hour and swiftness, have similar vector representations). As Firth (1957) famously said: "You shall know a word by the company it keeps"; building on this intuition, word vectors encompass the company they keep, and their proximity in a multidimensional space provides a way to gauge the semantic distance between different words.

Vector space semantic models have been shown to predict a wide range of behavioral phenomena, including similarity judgments, categorization, free association, text comprehension, semantic priming, probability judgments and forecasting, stereotyping and social judgments, consumer choice, and perceptions of risk (see Bhatia et al., 2019;Bullinaria & Levy, 2007;Jones et al., 2015). Natural language processing has also previously been used to study the association between psychological distance and abstractness (e.g., Bhatia & Walasek, 2016). Here, we wanted to incorporate the distributional representation approach to study the association between abstractness and speed. We hypothesized that the more concrete a concept is, the higher the meaning similarity it would show to the concept fast, as compared to the concept slow (Hypothesis 2c).

div.head: Method
div.p: We tested the relationship between slow-fast and concreteness using a data set of concreteness word ratings compiled by Brysbaert et al. (2014). The corpus consists of 39,954
English lemmas for which human participants coded ratings from abstract (1) to concrete (5).
We filtered out bigrams (word pairs such as sweet potato and tennis ball) and the words slow and fast, leaving a final corpus of 37,056 words.

To assess the semantic proximity of each word to the concepts slow and fast we took a word-embeddings approacha latent representation of words derived from a large body of text (e.g., Mikolov et al., 2013;Pennington et al., 2014). In this approach, word cooccurrences in large corpora are reduced to N-dimensions. Each word is then represented by a vector of length N that encompasses latent features of the word. This allows for algebraic operations on the vectors to extract meaningful relationships between concepts. A common method to gauge similarity between concepts is to calculate the cosine similarity between two vectors (Singhal, 2001).

In the current study, we extracted pre-trained word vectors from the fastText language model (Bojanowski et al., 2017). This model was trained on the English Wikipedia and English Common Crawl (i.e., random sampling from the internet), and produces word vectors of 300 dimensions. For each word in the Brysbaert et al. 2014corpus, we calculated a cosine similarity value with the vectors of slow and fast.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: For each word vector in the corpus we calculated a difference score of the cosine similarity between fast and slow, such as = ( , ) -( , ). If this value is positive, it means that word is semantically closer to fast than slow, and the opposite for negative values. Note that calculating a difference score of the cosine similarity in the semantic space is equivalent to projecting the vector onto an anchored semantic space (Grand et al., 2022). This metric enables measuring the relative distance of each concept from Fast as compared to Slow, and allows us to correlate two related continuums: (1) fast to slow and (b) abstract to concrete.
We next calculated the Pearson correlation of the difference scores (see distribution in the ESM) with concreteness norms (see distribution in the ESM), resulting in 30,955
observations. In line with our hypothesis, the difference scores were positively correlated with levels of concreteness, r (30,953) =.24, p < .001 (see Fig. 4).

Difference Fast-Slow Concreteness Figure 4. Concreteness of a word by its association with the vector of "Fast" versus the vector of "Slow" (difference between how strongly it is associated with Fast minus how strongly it is associated with Slow) (Study 7). The scatter plot presents a random sample of 20% of the dataset to avoid excessive clutter.

As predicted (Hypothesis 2c), the more concrete a word, the greater its tendency to appear in semantic proximity to the concept fast as compared to the concept slow. Thus, the structure of word distribution in natural language seems to support the existence of a mental association between speed and abstractness.

div.head: Study 8 The Effect of Construal Level on Speed of Change, Controlling for Valence and
Arousal
div.p: Construal level and speed are logically related, because high construals (decontextualized, abstract, central features of objects) are slower to change than low construals (contextualized, concrete, secondary features of objects). This study, unlike most other studies in the present paper, focuses on the speed of change rather than speed of motion.

As explained in the introduction, speed of change is the more general term, of which speed of motion is a specific case (where the change is in relative location) and our theory predicts that construal level would be associated with the speed of change (and not only with speed of motion). For example, abstract categories are slower to change than concrete categories. Thus, when walking down the produce aisle in the supermarket, displays of specific itemspeaches, apples, or grapesare faster to change than the category "fruit". The present study set to empirically test the relation between construal level and speed of change.

Study 8 examined whether situations described in more abstract terms would be perceived as slower to change (Hypothesis 2d). Participants were presented with short descriptions of situations, each via a single short sentence comprising a subject and predicate, and were asked to indicate how quickly or slowly the situation would change. We used the four increasingly more abstract categories identified by Semin and Fiedler (1988;1991; descriptive action verbs (DAVs), interpretative action verbs (IAVs), state verbs (SVs), and adjectives (ADJs). To rule out valence and arousal as alternative explanations for speed of change in selecting the terms we made sure that (a) half the terms in each category were positive in valence and half were negative in valence, and (b) the mean arousal level associated with the four categories was similar. We hypothesized that participants would perceive situations described by abstract terms as likely to change more slowly. Method Participants. One hundred and eight (73 females, Mage = 26.47, SD = 4.13) participated in the study. One was excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM 7 ). Thus, 107 participants were included in the analysis.

Materials and Procedure. In each trial participants were presented with a sentence describing a situation, with either one of four types of predicates, as follows (from the lowest level to highest level of construal): DAV (e.g., "Rebecca strokes Sharon"); IAV (interpretative action verb, e.g., "Jonathan flatters Stephen"); SV (state verb, e.g., "Jacob disdains Gary"); and adjective (e.g., "James is outgoing") (Semin & Fiedler, 1988). Their task was to estimate how quickly or slowly the described situation would change, and to indicate its speed of change on a 175 mm slider anchored at "Quickly" on the left and "Slowly" on the right. Distance from the left end of the slider (1-100) served as the dependent variable (higher numbers indicate a slower speed of change). In total, there were 48 sentences, twelve from each category. DAVs, IAVs, and SVs were adopted from Hoorens et al. (2012), and ADJs were adopted from Semin and Fiedler (1988). Half the terms in each category were positive in valence (higher than the median valence by the norms of Warriner et al., 2013) and half were negative (lower than the median valence). The terms in all four categories had similar arousal levels (DAVs: Mean = 4.99, SD = 0.78; IAVs: Mean = 5.06, SD = 0.98, SVs: Mean = 4.78, SD = 0.87; ADJs Mean= 5.00, SD = 0.55).

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: As predicted (Hypothesis 2d), a repeated-measures analysis on perceived speed of change of the situation yielded a significant effect of construal level, F (3,318) Semin and Fiedler (1988) demonstrated that the linguistic categories they identified differ on a dimension they labeled "temporal stability," which might seem similar to our notion of "speed." We should note, however, that this similarity is more apparent than real, as it is greater on the theoretical level than operationally. Specifically, they operationalized "temporal stability" by the question "How enduring a quality does the attribute (action) in this sentence express about the subject?" This operationalization does not fully correspond to speed of change of the referred-to situation, which is our focus of interest. For example, research on spontaneous trait inferences (Winter & Uleman, 1984) found that people readily infer enduring stable characteristics of actors from actions that are described by descriptive action verbs, which are fairly concrete (e.g., "John kicked a cat" may be seen as expressing the enduring quality "John is aggressive," and at the same time as describing a situation that would change quickly)."

Study 8 examines our hypothesis with respect to the effect of construal level on speed of change for verbs and actions. Future research may want to examine noun categories. For example, we could measure the speed at which categories vs. exemplars are expected to change as one moves about in natural environments. We would expect categories such as furniture, people, or food to change more slowly than their particular exemplars when one moves about in a relevant environment, such as a restaurant.

div.head: Study 9: The Effect of Speed on Construal Level
div.p: If indeed speed and construal level are associated, then a stimulus's speed and its construal level may be congruent or incongruent: high-level construals of a stimulus should be relatively easier to process when the stimulus is associated with slowness, whereas its lowlevel construals should be relatively easier to process when the stimulus is associated with speed (Hypothesis 2e; see Cian et al., 2015, for a similar rationale). Thus, given the choice between construing a stimulus at a high or low level, people should be more likely to choose a high construal level when the stimulus is slow rather than fast. Study 9 tested this hypothesis.

According to Wegner's (1987, 1989) action identification theory, actions (e.g., conducting a study) may be represented in terms of superordinate goals, meaning the ends for which we perform the action (e.g., advancing science), or in terms of subordinate goalsi.e., the means by which we perform it (e.g., testing a hypothesis). The former, high-level action identification is associated with why we perform an action, while the latter, low-level action identification is associated with how we perform it. Ample evidence suggests that people choose higher-level construals for more distal (as compared to near)
behaviors (Day & Bartels, 2004;Grinfeld et al., 2021;Libby et al., 2009;Liberman & Trope, 1998;Liviatan et al., 2008;Sánchez et al., 2020;Wakslak et al., 2006).

In Study 9 we examined whether the speed at which an action is imagined to be performed (slow or fast) affects whether it is construed in terms of the ends for which it is performed (high-level, "why" terms) or the means by which it is performed (low-level, "how" terms). Participants were presented with common behaviors (e.g., opening a door) and were asked to imagine that the behavior was performed either slowly or fast. For each behavior, participants indicated which of two alternative descriptions or action identifications best fit the behavior: a high-level or low-level action identification. If congruence exists between how people construe a behavior and its speed, then participants should prefer high-level action identifications to a greater extent for actions they imagined were performed slowly, and lowlevel action identifications to a greater extent for actions they imagined were performed quickly.

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. One hundred and fifteen participants (55 females, Mage = 28.12, SD = 5.62) took part in the study. Five were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM). Overall, 110 participants were included in the analysis.

Materials and Procedure. Participants were told that every action can be described in various ways. For example, the behavior typing a document might be described as pressing down keys or as expressing thoughts. Participants were then presented with a series of stimuli (22 stimuli in all), each comprising a short action together with two descriptions (the stimuli were borrowed from Vallacher & Wegner's [1989] Behavior Identification Form and translated into Hebrew). One of the descriptions in each set was at a high construal level, focusing on the ends for which the action is performed (the why), and the other was at a low construal level, focusing on the means by which the action is performed (the how).

Participants' task was to quickly and intuitively choose the description which best fits the action. The why description appeared to the right of the how description in half the trials, and to the left in the other half.

Before being presented with every action, participants were asked either to imagine it being performed slowly by someone living in a place characterized by a slow pace of life, or to imagine it being performed quickly by someone living in a fast-paced society. To strengthen the speed manipulation, at the beginning of each trial participants were presented with the floating dots animation used in Study 4. They were told that the moving dots simulate the speed at which they should imagine the action being performed and the pace of life they should call to mind. The speed at which each action was to be imagined was counterbalanced across the two versions of the experiment.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: For each participant the proportion of high-construal descriptions chosen as best fitting the action was computed separately for actions that were imagined to be performed slowly and for actions imagined to be performed quickly. We conducted a 2 (speed: Slow vs. Fast) X 2 (version: 1 or 2) mixed ANOVA with the first variable as a within-participants factor and the second as a between-participants factor. This analysis found no effect of version, F (1, 108) = 0.47, p = .495, η 2 p = .004, 95% CI [0.00, 0.06], and no interaction, F(1, 108) = 1.55, p = .216, η 2 p = .01, 95% CI [0.00, 0.09], but only a main effect of speed: high-construal descriptions were chosen to a greater extent when the action was imagined being performed Thus, supporting Hypothesis 2e, participants preferred high-level action identifications to a greater extent when they imagined the action being performed slowly relative to quickly, and they preferred low-level action identifications to a greater extent when they imagined the action being performed quickly relative to slowly.

A caveat to the findings of Study 9 should be noted. In this study, participants were asked to imagine certain behaviors being conducted quickly or slowly, and then to choose between high and low construals of each behavior (goals vs. means). In real life, however, many other factors may interfere with such judgments. For example, performing certain actions slowly may reflect difficulty (e.g., lifting a heavy load, walking over uneven ground).
We found that slowness reflects a higher construal level, but difficultywhich is associated with slownessis known to lower level of construal (Vallacher & Wegner, 1987, 1989.
Thus, the effects we hypothesized and found may be smaller and even reverse in real-life situations, in which slowness could be interpreted as reflecting difficulty.

div.head: Study Set III
div.p: Study Set III was designed to examine implications of the hypothesized associations between speed, psychological distance, and construal level in the domains of communication (Hypothesis 3) and person perception (Hypothesis 4).

div.head: Study 10a: Implications of the Associations between Speed (Slow vs. Fast) and Both
Psychological Distance and Construal Level for Communication
div.p: The social role of speed of speech in communication has been mainly examined with respect to the speaker's confidence and credibility. For example, in several studies, fast speech was found to convey higher credibility and confidence on the part of the speaker, and to facilitate persuasion through these cues (Guyer et al., 2019;Mehrabian & Williams, 1969;Miller et al., 1976;Scherer et al., 1973).

In the present study we looked at another potential ramification of fast versus slow speech. If indeed the speed of a stimulus affects its psychological distance (as suggested by the results of Study 4), then one possible implication is that slow-paced spoken messages will be perceived as addressing spatially and socially more distant audiences than fast-paced messages (H3a & H3b). Furthermore, findings by Joshi, Wakslak and colleagues (2014, 2016 suggest that larger audiences are experienced as being more spatially and socially distant, and are also associated with more abstract messages. If, as suggested by our findings, speed is associated with both psychological distance and construal level, then the pace of speech may also influence perceived audience size, with a slow-paced spoken message perceived as addressing a larger audience, and a fast-paced spoken message as addressing a smaller audience (H3c). . For each pair, the two audios were displayed side-by-side, labeled audio 1 and audio 2. In one experimental version ("V1") the fast audio appeared to the right in two of the three pairs (the first and third), and to the left in the remaining pair; in the other experimental version ("V2") these positions were reversed.

For each pair, after listening to both recordings, participants were asked to make a series of three judgments about the two audios in that pair, by dragging and dropping each audio into one of two boxes. The three sets of boxes were labeled "For an audience spatially close to [/ spatially distant from] the speaker"; "For a socially close [/ socially distant] audience"; and "For a large [/ a single-person] audience." For each pair and judgment, only one audio could be placed in each box (e.g., if one audio was placed in the "spatially close" box, the other had to go in the "spatially distant" box). Participants were asked to make each judgment based on their gut feeling. As noted, participants completed each of the three judgments for each pair of audios, for nine judgments in all.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: For each judgment, we averaged participants' responses across the three audio pairs.

The key dependent variables were the proportions of audio pairs that were placed in accordance with the hypothesesi.e., the fast-paced audio placed in the spatially close, socially close, and small audience boxes, and the slow-paced audio placed in the spatially distant, socially distant, or large audience boxes.

With respect to the perceived spatial distance between the speaker and audience, the In conclusion, the results of Studies 10a support Hypotheses 3a, 3b and 3c in showing that slow-paced speeches are perceived as being delivered to a spatially and socially more distant audience, and to a larger audience, than fast-paced speeches.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: We analyzed the results the same way as in Study 10a. With respect to the perceived spatial distance between the speaker and audience, the proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.61 (SD = 0.34). A t-test comparing this proportion with the constant 0.5 yielded a significant difference, t(97) = 3.22, p = .002, d = 0.33, 95% CI Studies 10a and 10b focus on characteristics of the communication process (spatial and social distance between the speaker and audience, audience size). In our final study, Study 11, we examine implications for person perception, and specifically whether listeners attribute to the speaker a contractive versus expansive regulatory scope.

div.head: Study 11: Implications of the Associations for Person Perception -The Case of
Regulatory Scope
div.p: When taking a decision, making a plan, or communicating with others, one may take into account only proximal objects and places, immediate and highly probable consequences, and socially close people. This manner of self-regulation is said to reflect a contractive regulatory scopea perception of the self mainly in relation to what is psychologically close.

In contrast, in addition to taking into account what is psychologically close, one may take into account also distal objects and places, long-term and less likely consequences, and socially distant people. This manner of self-regulation is said to reflect an expansive regulatory scope, a perception of the self in relation to what is psychologically distant as well as what is psychologically close (Sverdlik et al., 2022;Trope et al., 2021). Importantly, a high construal level is assumed to support an expansive scope, whereas a low construal level is assumed to support a contractive scope (Trope et al., 2021).

Initial evidence suggests that people show meaningful individual differences in the breadth of scope that they tend to adopt (Levit et al., 2022;Sverdlik et al., 2022). We reasoned that if (a) construal level is associated with regulatory scope and (b) speed is associated with construal level, then perhaps the speed associated with a target person may affect how others infer the target person's regulatory scope.

In this study we examined whether the associations have implications for how observers infer the regulatory scope of a speaker allegedly describing a decision that she has to take. We hypothesized that people would associate a slow-paced spoken message with an expansive regulatory scope and a fast-paced spoken message with a contractive regulatory scope (H4). To allow for the spoken message to allegedly reflect a contractive or expansive regulatory scope we wanted the message to be free of semantic content, and thus used a message recorded in a foreign language (Finnish for Hebrew speakers).

div.head: Method
div.p: Participants. One hundred and thirty-one volunteers (99 females, Mage = 27.66, SD = 4.22) participated in the study. Fifteen were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details are available in the ESM). Thus, 116 participants were included in the analysis.

Materials and Procedure. Participants were told that at times people take into consideration broad, global implications of their decisions, and at other times they take into account narrow, local implications. Participants were presented with three pairs of recorded messages in Finnish (the same pairs of messages used in Study 10b). However, in this study we told participants that all the speakers were describing decisions they faced, and the considerations they were taking into account. As before, each pair consisted of two recordings of the same spoken message, played at different speeds (a fast-paced version and a slowpaced version). For each of the messages, the audios were displayed side-by-side, and labeled audio 1 and audio 2. Again, in one experimental version ("V1") the fast audio appeared to the right in two of the three pairs (the first and third) and to the left in the other pair, and in the other experimental version ("V2") these positions were reversed.

After listening to each pair of audios, participants were asked to make a judgment by dragging and dropping each audio into one of two boxes. ." As in the previous studies, for each pair only one audio could be placed in each box. Again, participants completed each of the three judgments for each pair of audios, for nine judgments in all.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: We averaged participants' responses across the three audio pairs. The key dependent variable was the proportion of audio pairs that were placed in accordance with the hypothesis the fast-paced audio placed in the contractive regulatory scope box, and the slow-paced audio placed in the expansive regulatory scope box.

The proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.69 (SD = 0.33). A t-test comparing this proportion with the constant 0.5 yielded a significant difference, t(115) = 6.05, p < . 001,d = 0.56,95% CI [0.36,0.76]. We also examined the effect separately for each of the experimental versions (this analysis was not preregistered). The effects did not vary between the experimental versions: MV1 = 0.69, SD = 0.33; MV2 = 0.68, SD = 0.34, t(114) = 0.13, p = .90.

The literature on person perception (Macrea & Bodenhausen, 2001;Moskowitz & Gill, 2013) and impression formation (Uleman & Kressel, 2013) has identified a plethora of cues utilized by perceivers to deduce a target person's personal attributes (Borkenau & Liebler, 1995;Hassin & Trope, 2000), motivational and affective states (Manera et al., 2011;Pollick et al., 2001), bodily states (Park et al., 2007;Schaller et al., 2003), and much more.
As of yet we are not aware of studies documenting cues that perceivers use to deduce a target person's regulatory scope.

The results of Study 11 support Hypothesis 4, showing that people associate slowpaced spoken messages with an expansive regulatory scope and fast-paced spoken messages with a contractive regulatory scope. These results suggest that speed, and in particular the speed of speech, serves as a potent cue for whether a speaker is taking into account more psychologically immediate or more distant considerations. By extension, this implies that by speaking fast, leaders and speakers in general can signal to listeners that their message/ decision making/ policy/ agenda is local, and matters for the here and now, and by speaking slowly speakers may signal that their message/ decision making/ policy/ agenda is universal, and that its implications transcend time and space.

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: Anyone who has read fairy tales aloud knows that their familiar opening lines -"Once upon a time, in a distant land…," "Far, far away…," "A long, long time ago"are most effective when pronounced slowly. Like Judy Garland's "Somewhere over the Rainbow," these lines send us to psychologically distant realms not only through their semantics, but also via their slow tempo. In 12 studies, we provide the first empirical support for the existence of mental associations between speed, on the one hand, and both psychological distance and construal level on the other.

As expected, in Study 1 participants demonstrated both implicit and explicit associations between psychological distance and speed. In Study 2, participants' choices showed that they regarded it as intuitively more correct to couple concepts exemplifying psychological distance (in all its four dimensions) with slow music and concepts exemplifying psychological proximity with fast music. In Study 3 we manipulated the psychological distance of stimuli and examined the effects on the speed associated with them. We found that participants attributed a slow pace of life to psychologically distant places more than to psychologically close places. In Study 4 we manipulated the speed associated with stimuli and examined the effects on their psychological distance. Behaviors visualized as being performed slowly were perceived as more imaginary (less real) than behaviors visualized as performed quickly.

Turning next to the hypothesized association with construal level, Study 5 did not reveal an implicit association between construal level and speed, but participants did explicitly associate the two dimensions. In Study 6, participants intuitively coupled abstract concepts with slow music and concrete concepts with fast music. In Study 7 we found that the more concrete a word, the greater its tendency to appear in semantic proximity in written texts to the concept fast as compared to the concept slow. In Study 8 we found that situations characterized by concrete terms were perceived as faster to change than situations characterized by abstract terms. In Study 9, we manipulated the speed associated with stimuli and examined the effect on construal level. Participants construed behaviors visualized as being performed slowly on a higher level, in terms of their goals rather than their means, than behaviors visualized as performed quickly.

Finally, we turned to implications of the associations for both communication and person perception. Studies 10a and 10b showed that people infer a larger spatial and social distance between a speaker and her audience, and a larger audience, from slow-paced speech compared to fast-paced speech. These findings suggest that speed, and in particular the speed of speech, serves as a potent cue for increasing or decreasing the psychological distance between a speaker and her audience, and for signaling the size of the audience the speaker aspires to address. Study 11 showed that people attribute a more expansive regulatory scope to a speaker who speaks relatively slowly (as compared to relatively fast). The findings of that study suggest that speed, and in particular the speed of speech, can signal the degree to which a target person is taking into account local and immediate (vs. broader and more remote)
considerations.

The association of speed with psychological distance and abstraction is well reflected in art and culture. For example, John Lennon's "Imagine" uses a slow tempo to take us to a hypothetical world, one where there are no possessions, no countries and no religion. By contrast, fast, upbeat pop music is all about inspiring us to live in "the here and now."
