Various advertising campaigns take advantage of this feature of musical tempo, encouraging us to savor the moment and indulge in the concrete pleasures of our bodies and senses (by buying their product). 10 Art and culture also often exhibit a simultaneous association of speed and vertical position, such that psychological distance is induced both by slow tempo and by reference to elevated locations (e.g., in the songs "Over the Rainbow," 11 "When You Wish Upon a Star,"

or "Beyond the Sky" ; see Nussinson et al., 2019Nussinson et al., , 2021Van Kerckhove et al., 2015 for studies on the association of vertical position with psychological distance and level of construal). This power multiplier is used to great effect in the sharp contrast between the slow-paced, up-oriented song "Part of Your World," sung by Ariel, the Little Mermaid, when she fantasizes about (for her, far and unlikely) life on land, 14 and the fast-paced, downoriented song "Kiss the Girl" (AKA "Under the Sea"), sung by her old friend Sebastian, the crab, who tries to convince her of the benefits of her real life underwater. 15 We can see a similar pairing between "slow" and "high" in popular meditation videos which couple slow music with elevated landscapes (e.g., clouds or mountains). 16

div.head: Potential Underlying Mechanisms
div.p: Probably, the examples adduced above "work" because they reflect the poetic language spoken by our own minds. That is, we believe that the findings presented in this article reflect mental associations between speed and psychological distance, and between speed and construal level. What, then, are the underlying processes through which these relationships are established within people's mental lives?

While our findings are silent as to the specific process or processes that underlie these associations, we can suggest several contributory mechanisms. First, both psychological distance and construal level are logically related to speed. When considered in light of logicalfunctional principles (Gilead et al., 2020(Gilead et al., , 2021, the associations may reflect the facts that what is more spatially distant is necessarily slower to affect us (speed-spatial distance); that what is slower necessarily affects us later (speed-temporal distance); and that higher-level aspects of an object change more slowly across repeated interactions with it (speed-construal level) Hansen & Trope, 2013;Trope & Liberman, 2010). We assume that because social distance and hypothetical distance are associated with spatial distance, temporal distance, and construal level (both in our minds and in the world) and are automatically activated by them, they too become mentally associated with speed.

A second type of explanation draws on the cognitive-ecological approach (Fiedler, 2014(Fiedler, , 2020Pleskac & Hertwig, 2014; and see also Fiedler et al., 2012;Fiedler et al., 2015). It notes built-in associations in the environment, such that a stimulus which is farther away generally moves more slowly on the retina, and is responded to more slowly by the cognitive system.

Note that although from this perspective the association between speed and spatial distance is the root cause for the associations between speed and the other dimensions of psychological distance and between speed and construal level, we believe that once formed, these mental associations have a life of their own. They might be strengthened in their own right, for example through couplings prevalent in art, language, and culture more generally (see below;

and see Schubert et al., 2011, Figure 2, for a similar conceptualization). Thus, deriving the hypothesized associations from the cognitive-ecological approach to cognition does not imply that our effects should be stronger for spatial distance as compared to the other dimensions of psychological distance (and see the results of Study 2); nor does it imply that the associations with higher construal levels are mediated through perceptions of spatial distance.

The associations between speed, psychological distance, and construal level may also be generated or strengthened by embodiment effects and conceptual metaphor effects. An embodiment approach (Barsalou, 2008(Barsalou, , 2016 might suggest that images which move more slowly on the retina typically represent more physically distant objects. As a result of this association (Gibson, 1950), information processing about spatially distant objects is repeatedly coupled with the proprioception of low-speed movement on the retina, while information processing about spatially close objects is coupled with the proprioception of high-speed movement on the retina. Under these conditions, perceptual experiences associated with distance in space are likely to be schematized, such that thinking about spatial distance would involve perceptual simulation of low-speed movement (in contrast to highspeed movement).

Conceptual metaphor explanations (Casasanto, 2017;Landau et al., 2010) suggest that people may rely on information about the source dimension of speed (fast vs. slow) when they reason about, interpret, or evaluate the target dimensions of psychological distance and abstractness in relation to a given stimulus. The basis for this conceptual mapping would presumably be the same association between the spatial distance of a stimulus and the multiple facets of speed as detailed above (Gibson, 1950;Maren, 2007;Mobbs et al., 2007;Previc, 1990). The manipulation of speed to foster psychological distancing and abstractness in art and culture, as described above, is in line with the conceptual metaphor approach and with the notion of metaphoric transfer (Landau et al., 2010).

The findings of Study 7 offer support for several of these different theories. To some, the fact that concrete words were more likely to be paired in written texts with the concept fast as compared to the concept slow may seem to support a cognitive-ecological approach, in the sense that the associations could be afforded by the ecology of word associations. Note, however, that while these naturalistically observed associations in written language could serve as a basis for learning the associations (and see Hauser & Schwarz, 2022), they are at the same time a reflection of the associations in people's minds. Alternatively, the fact that we were able to validate the associations in an NLP study where the input is entirely linguistic may reflect the fact that the associations are symbolic. Again, however, note that the corpora on which our NLP analysis was run are the products of embodied minds.

We may further profit from considering the reported effects in terms of the semantic space and meaning (Osgood & Suci, 1955). The quick-slow scale forms part of Osgood's activity dimension, along with active-passive and hot-cold. Thus, quick is active while slow is passive. At the same time, activity, acting on the world, is associated withand may even demanda lower construal level than passivity. For example, the linguistic category model (Semin & Fiedler, 1988) suggests that passive states are more abstract than active ones.

Notably, this model is aligned with the constraints that distance imposed until relatively recently on human activity: in pre-modern life, one could only act directly on stimuli in one's immediate surroundings (i.e., stimuli that were spatially, temporally, and socially close);

relationships with psychologically remote stimuli were by nature passive, limited to "state verbs" such as contemplation (for a related argument see Gilead et al., 2014). This analysis may suggest that the associations exemplified in our studies between both psychological distance and construal level, on the one hand, and speed on the other, may reflect to some extent a more general mental association of both psychological distance and construal level with activity. Indeed, we believe that both line of theorizing co-exist.

Another factor to consider is arousal. As speed is interrelated with activity, and because activity is often associated with arousal, one may assume that speed and arousal are often interrelated in one's experience. Thus, to the extent that the activity dimension is somehow more overarching, our findings may be seen, at least in theory, as a specific example of a more general association with activity, and thus perhaps with arousal.
Importantly, however, our results do seem to be more consistent with a more specific effect of speed rather than arousal. First, further analysis of the data of our Study 7 (the NLP study)

provides us with a unique opportunity to delve into the relationship between the concreteness of concepts, their relative distance in semantic space from fast as compared to slow, and the arousal levels associated with them. To assess the arousal associated with speed and construal level we used arousal ratings taken from Warriner et al. (2013). The zero-order correlation between concreteness and arousal was negative: r (13,325) = -.17, p < .0001. The zero-order correlation between arousal and speed was very weak and negative: r (13,325) = -.06, p < .0001. We then fitted a linear model to predict concreteness with speed and arousal. The model was statistically significant (R2 = 0.09, F(2, 13301) = 648.39, p < .001, adj. R2 = 0.09).

Importantly, whereas the effect of speed was statistically significant and positive (b = 4.88,95% CI [4.56,5.20] [-0.17, -0.14]). Thus, whereas the closer a concept is to fast as compared to slow the more concrete it is, the more a concept loaded on arousal, the less concrete it is. This suggests that the association between speed and construal level is, at least in part, independent of the association between arousal and construal level.

Also of note, Study 8 demonstrated an effect of construal level on perceived speed that is independent of arousal. Specifically, the more abstract the term describing a situationfrom DAVs to IAVs to SVs to ADJs (Semin & Fiedler, 1988)the slower the situation was expected to change, despite the fact that all four categories of terms were equal in their arousal level. This further suggests that the association between speed and construal level is at least partly independent of the association between arousal and construal level.

Finally, in some of the studies reported above, differences between versions emerged in the strength of the effects connecting speed to distance and construal level. Specifically, in studies conducted in English (Studies 1 and 5) the associations between fast/psychologically close/concrete and between slow/psychologically distant/abstract were stronger in versions of the studies where the concept "fast" was presented to the left of the concept "slow." In Study 10a, which was conducted in Hebrew, these associations were stronger in a version where the concept that represented "fast" (e.g., faster-paced audios) was presented mainly to the right of the concept that represented "slow." In Studies 10b and 11, which were conducted in Hebrew but involved Finnish-speaking audios, no differences between versions emerged. When viewed in light of the Social Agency Bias (SAB) model (Suitner & Maass, 2016), these differences may reflect rightwards versus leftwards writing/reading habits. According to this model, for English readers what is on the left is more agentic, and hence associated with more

speed, than what is on the right, whereas for Hebrew readers the reverse is true. Thus, experimental versions which are compatible with this mapping may yield stronger associations between the dimensions.

div.head: Theoretical Implications
div.p: Our findings have a range of potential theoretical ramifications. First, if, as suggested by our findings, a stimulus's psychological distance and construal level are associated in our minds with its speed, it is possible that the association between psychological distance and construal level is driven at least in part by their mutual associations with speed. Repeatedly throughout each day, stimuli that move more slowly on our retina, and to which we respond more slowlyin other words, spatially distant stimuliare construed both as psychologically more distant (on the different dimensions) and as more abstract. It is possible that this coupling feeds into the psychological distance-construal level association and facilitates the emergence of construal-level effects.

Second, our findings join dozens of findings inspired by the conceptual metaphor (Landau et al., 2010) and embodied cognition approaches (Barsalou, 2016;Matheson & Barsalou, 2018) which show that variation on one dimension of conscious experience imbues our experience on seemingly unrelated dimensions. For instance, previous findings have pointed to effects of social exclusion on perceived ambient temperature (Zhong & Leonardelli, 2008); effects of weight on perceptions of importance (Chandler et al., 2012;Jostmann et al., 2009), severity (Kaspar, 2013), and disability (Stroch et al., 2019); and effects of vertical position on perceptions of power (Giessner & Schubert, 2007;Schubert, 2005), valence (Meier & Robinson, 2004), and psychological distance and construal level (Nussinson et al., 2019;. In the same way, our current findings suggest that speed colors perceptions of psychological distance and construal level. Our findings thus join the long tradition of embodiment research in unveiling a little further the language of our subjective experiences.

Third, on an even more general level, our results may have implications for possible associations between dimensions of meaning. Specifically, as noted above, Bentler and LaVoie (1972) propose reality (i.e., the distinction between real and non-real) as one of seven dimensions of meaning that extend the semantic space beyond the three dimensions of meaning proposed by Osgood, namely evaluation, potency, and activity (Osgood & Suci, 1955). According to Bentler and LaVoie (1972), the reality dimension comprises such scales as imaginary-actual, fantasized-truthful, and abstract-concrete, and thus seems to partially map onto psychological distance and construal level. As noted earlier, the quick-slow scale, on the other hand, is part of Osgood's activity dimension. Our findings naturally raise the question as to whether the documented associations between speed and abstractness and between speed and psychological distance attest more broadly to an association between the reality and activity dimensions of meaningand if so, what are the implications of this association.

Finally, a comparison between our findings and those of Shani-Feinstein et al. (2022) is theoretically telling. Shani-Feinstein and her colleagues found that when actually or virtually moving faster, people rely on more abstract mental representations during decision making. These findings are seemingly contradictory to ours. Note, however, that Shani-Feinstein et al. manipulated the perceived moving speed of their participants (e.g., being in a slow vs. a fast train) and found that participants who move faster use higher-level construals.

In contrast, our studies manipulate the perceived speed associated with the stimulus. This reversal in the associations goes hand in hand with previous findings showing opposite associations between dimensions of meaning when the self serves as a reference point (as in Shani-Feinstein et al.) versus when the object serves as a reference point (as in our studies).

For example, Seibt et al. (2008) showed that when induced into a self-as-reference-point perspective (thinking about arm movements as decreasing vs. increasing distance from the self), participants are faster to move a joystick toward the self (and away from the screen) in response to positive words and away from the self (and toward the screen) in response to negative words. In contrast, when induced into an object-as-reference-point perspective (thinking in terms of decreasing vs. increasing distance from the word), participants are faster to move a joystick toward the screen in response to positive words and away from the screen in response to negative words. Thus, the very same bodily feedback is construed in opposing ways (as approach vs. avoidance behavior) depending on participants' frame of reference.

Similarly, both Aggarwal and Zhao (2015) and Slepian et al. (2015) using the self as reference pointshow that participants who experience themselves in a higher position looking down (e.g., from the top of a descending staircase) use a higher construal level than those who experience themselves in a lower position looking up (e.g., from the bottom of an ascending staircase). In contrast, using the object as reference point, we show (Nussinson et al., , 2021) that looking at stimuli located at the top of a screen results in a higher construal level than looking down at the bottom of the screen. Again, the very same bodily feedback is associated in opposing ways with construal level depending on participants' frame of reference. We thus contend that in a similar manner, high speed is associated with a high construal level when (as in Shani-Feinstein et al.) the self serves as a reference point, and with a low construal level when (as in our studies) the stimulus serves as a reference point.

div.head: Practical Implications
div.p: Psychological distance and construal level have been shown to affect judgments, preferences, and subjective experiences (see 2014;Liberman et al., 2007;Trope & Liberman, 2010). The present findings suggest that because speed is associated with distance and construal level, manipulating speed may exert effects on our judgments, subjective experiences, and preferences that are similar to those of distancing and abstraction.

The results of Studies 10a and 10b seem to suggest that speed, and in particular speed of speech, serves as a potent cue for increasing or decreasing the psychological distance between a speaker and her audience. By speaking fast, speakers may signal to their listeners that they are similar to them, and that they are speaking to them intimately and personally. We live in an era when much human communication is conducted via technology (e.g., cellular phones, videoconferencing software, social media) and involves built-in spatial distance between communicators (Ruben et al., 2021;Watt, 2010). (that is yet to be examined) is that as power is associated with both greater experienced psychological distance from others (Magee & Smith, 2013) and with abstract information processing (Smith & Trope, 2006), slow speech signals power. Future research may want to examine whether our findings extend to written messages as wellthat is, whether the speed associated with written messages (e.g., via slow-vs fast-moving dots in the background, or text that scrolls quickly or slowly)has comparable effects on communication.

Furthermore, the results of Study suggest that perceivers may use the speed of a spoken message to infer the speaker's (current or chronic) regulatory scope. Fast speech may suggest that the speaker is planted in the here and now, that her decisions and agendas take into account local, immediate, and high-likelihood considerations, whereas slow speech may suggest that her decisions and agendas take into account psychologically more distant consideration, are more universal, and have implications that transcend time and space (see Martin Luther Kings's "I have a dream" speech, August 18, 1963). Here again, this cue may be especially critical in modern times, when social leaders, politicians, business figures, and scientists alike manage how others perceive them from a built-in distance.

Of course, the design of Studies 10a, 10b and 11 is somewhat artificial, in that participants were exposed to both slow-and fast-paced speech, and were asked to consider both with respect to the DV (characteristics of the communication or perceived regulatory scope). Future studies should examine these effects in real lifefor example, comparing how leaders are perceived as a function of their pace of speech (see Grinfeld et al., 2021, for a discussion of the importance of explicit comparison in CL research and beyond).
Those caveats aside, from a practical perspective, the associations reported in this paper have a range of potential implications in various realms. We point here to a few of these.

One set of potential implications relates to priming effects. It is possible that when making a decision, the same event, plan, option or idea may be perceived as less likely, more hypothetical, or more distant in time or space when presented (e.g., read or displayed) at a slow (rather than fast) pace, or when accompanied by slow (vs fast) music. Similarly, when primed with slow stimuli (as compared to fast stimuli), people may perceive unknown target persons as less familiar and less similar to the self (that is, as psychologically more distant;

see Stephan et al., 2011), and may construe the self more in terms of invariable traits (as opposed to changing depending on the situation) (see Nussbaum et al., 2003, Study 4;Pronin & Ross, 2006;Wakslak et al., 2008). Inducing slowness in decision making may increase the salience of desirability concerns as opposed to feasibility concerns (see Liberman & Trope, 1998;Liviatan et al., 2008;Todorov et al., 2007), and of pros as opposed to cons (see Eyal et al., 2004;Herzog et al., 2007). Finally, inducing a slow pace may strengthen the role of values in shaping people's behavioral intentions with respect to future situations (see Eyal et al., 2008;Eyal et al., 2009), and increase the weighting of high-level concerns over low-level concerns in self-regulation, thereby helping people avoid giving in to temptation . It is further possible that priming negotiators with slow-paced stimuli may promote logrolling or concession-making on low-priority issues in exchange for favorable outcomes on high-priority issues (Henderson et al., 2006;Henderson & Trope, 2009;Kelley, 1966). On the other hand, it is also possible that speed dating (where potential partners serve as rapidly changing stimuli) makes parties consider each other in a concrete, low-level manner.

Second, ample evidence suggests that processing of a stimulus is facilitated when associated dimensions of the stimulus match (Chae & Hoegg, 2013;Cian et al., 2015;Deng & Kahn, 2009;Hilbert et al., 2014;Meier & Robinson, 2004;Romero & Biswas, 2016;Sherman & Clore, 2009). Based on our findings, information that is abstract and psychologically distant may be easier to process when presented at a slow pace or accompanied by slow music, whereas information that is concrete and psychologically proximal may be easier to process when presented at a fast pace or accompanied by fast music. Note that we do not claim or predict that proximate and concrete information will be processed more deeply (Craik & Lockhart, 1972) when it is presented at a fast pace, but rather only that it will be more compatible and easier to process (i.e., its processing will be more fluent) when associated with a fast pace, whereas distant and abstract information will be more compatible and easier to process when associated with a slow pace. A concomitant possible implication is that proximate and concrete information "feels right" when associated with speed, whereas distant and abstract information "feels right" when associated with slowness (Begg et al., 1992;Dechêne et al., 2010;Reber & Schwarz, 1999;Unkelbach, 2007).

Furthermore, based on the notion that the fluency with which a message is processed contributes to its persuasiveness (Aaker & Lee, 2001;Amit et al., 2012;Briñol et al., 2013;Lee & Aaker, 2004), we might predict that messages and ads involving abstract values and long-term goals (e.g., health, sustainability, security, charity) and psychologically distant objects (e.g., retirement, a vacation destination, luxuries) may be processed more fluently and hence may be more convincing when presented at a slow pace. In contrast, messages involving concrete concepts (e.g., how to solve a concrete problem, such as opening a plugged pipe) and psychologically close objects (e.g., immediate hunger, thirst, bodily sensations, everyday scenarios) may be easier to process and hence more convincing when presented at a fast pace.
Our findings may also be of interest and importance for those who design the spaces around us, such as architects, landscape designers, urban planners, and policy makers.

Specifically, with the development of technology, human work and living environments are increasingly characterized by higher speeds (e.g., of information transfer, of surrounding stimuli). Our studies suggest that this trend may inadvertently contract our minds to pay attention to more proximate times, locations, persons and possibilities, as well as to induce low construal levels (Trope et al., 2021). If some of these effects are undesirable, we might be able to offset them by designating specific places (neighborhoods, parks, rooms) or times (e.g., days or hours) to be characterized by a slower pace.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: We found that construal level and psychological distance are associated with speed, such that the speed of a stimulus affects both its construal level and its psychological distance, and vice versa. These results contribute to our understanding of the language of the mind and also may have practical implications for communication, person perception, decision making, negotiation, behavioral intentions, and urban design.

figure.head: MethodParticipants.
figure.figDesc: One hundred and eight volunteers (78 females, Mage = 28.65, SD = 4.19) participated in the study. Nine were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM). Thus, 99 participants were included in the analysis. Materials and Procedure. Participants were presented with three pairs of recorded messages, and were told that a speaker had recorded them for an audience. Each pair consisted of the same spoken message played at different speeds (a fast-paced version and a slow-paced version). The messages were all short (18 words in messages 1 and 3; 26 words in message 2)

proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.72 (SD = 0.31). A t-test comparing this proportion with the constant 0.5 yielded a significant difference, t(98) = 7.22, p < .001, d = 0.73, 95% CI [0.50, 0.95]. Likewise, for the perceived social distance between the speaker and audience, the proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.75 (SD = 0.33), t(98) = 7.46, p < .001, d = 0.75, 95% CI [0.53, 0.97]. Finally, for the audience's size, the proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.69 (SD = 0.35), t(98) = 5.35, p < .001, d = 0.54, 95% CI [0.33, 0.75]. 8

12, 0.53]. Likewise, for social distance, the proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.66 (SD = 0.34). A t-test comparing this proportion with the constant 0.5 yielded a significant difference, t(97) = 4.75, p < .001, d = 0.48, 95% CI [0.27, 0.69]. Finally, for audience size, the proportion of pairs placed in congruence with the hypothesis was 0.69 (SD = 0.31). A t-test comparing this proportion with the constant 0.5 yielded a significant difference, t(97) = 6.29, p < .001, d = 0.64, 95% CI [0.42, 0.85]. Thus, the results of Study 10b replicate those of Study 10a in a foreign language.These findings join those of Study 10a in supporting H3a, H3b and H3c. Specifically, they show that slow-paced speech is perceived as being delivered to a spatially and socially more distant audience, and to a larger audience, than fast-paced speech; and that this holds even when the listener does not understand any of the content of the message. Indeed, the fact that the participants in Study 10b did not know the content of the message may have rendered pace of speech an even more potent cue. The results of Studies 10a and 10b thus complement each other in suggesting that the speed of speech serves as a potent cue for increasing or decreasing the psychological distance between a speaker and audience. In practice, this means that by speaking fast, speakers may signal to their listeners that they are similar to them, that they are socially and spatially close, and that they are speaking to each audience member personally. By speaking slowly, speakers may convey, rather, a sense of separatenessperhaps superiorityand distance. These findings, therefore, demonstrate an important potential implication of the basic association between slow-psychologically distant-abstract and fast-psychologically close-concrete for communication.

If, as suggested by our findings, the speed of speech is a modifier of social and perceived spatial distance, then shedding light on this role may contribute to our understanding of the dynamics of communication in general, and of communication via technology in particular. Furthermore, whereas until relatively recently in human history, speakers spoke to an audience of a known size, today politicians, social leaders, scientists, celebrities, and lay people alike use technology to approach audiences of unknown and ever changing size. If, as suggested by our findings, the speed of speech is a modifier of perceived audience size, then it is possible that speakers may fine-tune what they signal to listeners merely by adjusting their pace of speechconveying a sense of intimacy by speaking fast (with the implication that the speaker is addressing each listener personally), or slowing down so listeners feel part of an immense crowd. The remaining participants were asked to associate the eight words used for the concepts Slow and Fast with the concepts Abstract and Concrete (again, randomly assigned to the left and right, with Equal Association in the center). Responses were coded and recoded such that larger numbers indicated a stronger association with Slow or Abstract than with Fast or Concrete. The mean SPF score was relatively low, 0.002 (SD = 0.41), and was not significantly different from zero, t(475) = 0.15, p = .876, d = 0.01, 95% CI[-0.08, 0.10]. Thus, these findings do not support the existence of stronger associations between a high construal level and Slow and between a low construal level and Fast compared with the reverse. We also examined (in a non-preregistered analysis) whether the effect on the SPF scores depended on the positioning of the two speed concepts (i.e., whether Slow was to the left or the right). The effect of positioning had a moderate effect on the SPF scores, with lower scores under Slow-left and Fast-right compared with Slow-right and Fast-left, t(456) = 3.43, p < 0.001, d = 0.32, 95% CI [0.14, 0.51].5 We will return to these differences between the experimental versions in the General Discussion. Hypothesis 2a was not supported in this part of the study. As noted above, responses to the explicit association measures were coded such that larger numbers indicated a stronger association with Slow (rather than Fast) or Abstract (rather than Concrete).Associations with Slowness. For those questionnaires where the construal level concepts were rated on a Slow-Fast scale, we submitted the average reported associations (detailed in Table 2) to a 2 (construal level: Abstract, Concrete) x 2 (concept on the left of the VAS: Fast, Slow) mixed ANOVA. A main effect of construal level indicated that as hypothesized, participants associated abstract concepts more than concrete concepts with the category Slow, F(1, 226) = 11.21, p < .001, η 2 p = . 047, 95% CI [0.01, 0.11]. In addition, participants associated the concepts more with Slow when Slow was on the left side of the VAS than when it was on the right, F(1, 226) = 16.50, p < .001, η 2 p = .07, 95% CI [0.02, 0.14]. There was no significant interaction, F(1, 226) = 0.29, p = . 589, η 2 p = .001, 95% CI [0.00, 0.03]. Thus, the results indicate that participants explicitly associate a high construal level more than a low construal level with the category Slow (rather than Fast).

Together, the findings for the explicit measure support Hypothesis 2b.

figure.head: Study 10b: Implications of the Associations for Perception of Communication in a Foreign Language
figure.figDesc: Study 10b aimed to replicate the results of Study 10a with messages recorded in Finnish (a language that is not understood by our Hebrew-speaking participants). An advantage of switching to Finnish-language auditory messages is that we ensure the results are not mediated through different interpretations of the same content. In this design, unlike in Study 10a, participants were not able to lean on the content of the messages in guiding their judgments.
figure.note: Method Participants. One hundred and twelve volunteers (56 females, Mage = 29.18, SD = 3.72) participated in the study. Fourteen were excluded based on preregistered criteria (details in the ESM). Thus, 98 participants were included in the analysis. Materials and Procedure. Identical to Study 10a, except for the language of the messages. The same messages used in Study 10a were translated to Finnish and recorded in Finnish.
